lesson.title: Implementing In-App Analytics
lesson.summary: Learn how to use built-in events provided by Firebase Analytics and implement some of your own. Then, see how easy it is to tailor an app experience to segments of users with User Properties.

atoms.text:
# Setting Up Green Thumb

A Firebase project contains settings for Firebase tools. It can be linked to more than one app, which is useful when you want to make a version of the same app for different platforms. If you feel comfortable setting up a Firebase project, you can skip this section.

# Download Course Resources

Start by downloading the zipped file in the course resources or from GitHub: https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android

In order to bring in those powerful features we saw in the finished app, we need to create a project using the [Firebase console](https://console.firebase.google.com/). If you don’t have a Google account yet, you can create one [here](https://accounts.google.com/signup).


# Create Project in Firebase console

Welcome to the Firebase console!

and name your project.

In this case, the name of our app is GreenThumb, so let’s name the project GreenThumb as well.

Then, select the country/region of your organization/company. Your selection also sets the appropriate currency for your revenue reporting. The selected country does not determine the location of your data for Firebase features. Google may process and store Customer Data anywhere Google or its agents maintain facilities.
Once your project is created, you can see the project’s Overview page.

Take a moment to look at the Console home page for Green Thumb. You’ll see tabs on the left associated with Firebase features. Feel free to click on the tabs and see where they lead. If you would like to learn more about these features, check out the [Firebase website](https://firebase.google.com) or [Firebase in a Weekend: Android](https://www.udacity.com/course/firebase-in-a-weekend-by-google-android--ud0352), our course that covers several Firebase features. When you’re ready, move on to the next step in setting up your app.

To proceed with the setup, select **Add Firebase to your Android app**.

- **Package name**: Enter `com.google.firebase.udacity.greenthumb`.
- **App nickname (optional)**: You can leave it blank or add an optional name.
- **Debug signing certificate**: You don’t have to add a signing certificate SHA-1 here because we will not be using Dynamic Links, Invites, or Google Sign-In support. However, if you want to learn more about adding this for future apps you can check out this [link](https://developers.google.com/android/guides/client-auth).

When you are done, click the **Add App** button.

Move the resulting google-services.json download to the directory **GreenThumb/app** directory as instructed in step 2. When you are ready, press **Continue**.

# Add Dependencies for Firebase Analytics

Follow the instructions given in step 3. Open the project-level build.gradle file and add the following line to the `dependencies` block: 

```gradle
classpath 'com.google.gms:google-services:3.0.0'
```

atoms.caption: Navigate to the project-level build.gradle file (high-lighted). Make sure it's not the app-level one.
Add this dependency in the project-level build.gradle

atoms.text:
Then open the app-level build.gradle file and add this line to the bottom of the file. Make sure it's at the bottom (Read [this post](http://stackoverflow.com/a/38018985) to find out why order *does* matters):

```gradle
apply plugin: 'com.google.gms.google-services'
```


Android Studio will prompt you that the gradle files have changed and that the project should be synced. Click on "Sync Now" in the prompt or on the gradle sync icon in the toolbar

atoms.caption: Navigate to the app-level build.gradle file (high-lighted). Make sure it's not the project-level one.
Add this plugin at the bottom of the app-level build.gradle

atoms.text: Android Studio will prompt you that the gradle files have changed and that the project should be synced. Click on "Sync Now" in the prompt or on the gradle sync icon in the toolbar
When you are ready, click Finish back in the Firebase console.

tasks: Download the Android version of the Green Thumb app
Create a new Firebase project with the package name com.google.firebase.udacity.greenthumb
Add the google-services.json to the app level directory
Add the Firebase Analytics project-level & app-level gradle dependencies
atoms.positive_feedback: Great job! If you need more practice setting up Firebase projects, check out our Firebase intro course, [Firebase in a Weekend](https://www.udacity.com/course/firebase-in-a-weekend-by-google-android--ud0352)!
atoms.description: Check the tasks as you complete them. See the previous concept (Setting Up Green Thumb) for detailed instructions.

atoms.text:
- [Automatically Collected Events](https://support.google.com/firebase/answer/6317485?hl=en)

- [Automatically Collected User Properties](https://support.google.com/firebase/answer/6317486?hl=en&ref_topic=6317484)

- [Firebase documentation - DebugView](https://firebase.google.com/docs/analytics/debugview)

- Wondering why it takes so long for Firebase Analytics data to show up in the dashboard? Read the answer on [The Firebase Blog: "How Long Does it Take for My Firebase Analytics Data to Show Up?"](https://firebase.googleblog.com/2016/11/how-long-does-it-take-for-my-firebase-analytics-data-to-show-up.html).

- **ADB  Commands**
The instructor is running *adb* commands in the terminal which allow you to directly communicate with a connected device via the terminal. 

 If you are running into an issue when executing the same commands, it may be because you are running the command from a directory where the *adb* executable is not found. To run *adb* commands no matter which folder you’re in, follow [these setup instructions](http://lifehacker.com/the-easiest-way-to-install-androids-adb-and-fastboot-to-1586992378).

question.prompt: Run the Green Thumb app again and check out all of the different views and features. Which of these suggested event types would be useful to log in Green Thumb? Choose all that apply.

atoms.title: Logging Events
atoms.instructor_notes: Remember that it [can take up to 24 hours for Firebase to aggregate event metrics into reports](https://firebase.googleblog.com/2016/11/how-long-does-it-take-for-my-firebase-analytics-data-to-show-up.html) in the Firebase Analytics dashboard. You can use [DebugView](https://firebase.google.com/docs/analytics/debugview) during development to verify that event metrics are being sent to Firebase.

concepts.title: Exercise: Implementing Log to Cart Event

atoms.text:
# Exercise: Implementing Log to Cart Event

### Exercise Code
**[Starting Code](https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android/tree/L03.01-Solution-FirebaseSetUp)** for this Exercise

tasks: Determine in which method will log the event ADD_TO_CART
Determine where in the method body to log the event ADD_TO_CART
Log the event with Firebase Analytics
Run the app and see the event logged in logcat
Move the code to a static method called logEventAddToCart in a class called Analytics
atoms.description: Use the example we just completed together as a guide to determine where and how to log sendAddToCartEvent in the PastPurchasesViewController.

atoms.text:
# Exercise: Event Logging Practice 

### Exercise Code
**[Starting Code](https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android/tree/L03.02-Solution-LogAddToCartEvent)** for this Exercise

tasks: Log when a plant's detail is viewed.
Log when the shopping cart is viewed (i.e., when the user begins the checkout process).
Log when the shopping cart is checked out.
Log an event of your choice that you feel could provide useful data.
atoms.description: Here's some additional logging practice. Using what you've learned, add code to Green Thumb to log the events below with Firebase Analytics. Check that the events are recorded in logcat to verify that you are logging at the correct time with the correct data.

atoms.text:
# Exercise: Setting User Properties

### Exercise Code
**[Starting Code](https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android/tree/L03.04-Solution-SetUserProperty)** for this Exercise

tasks: Register the user properties in the Firebase console
Implement the method that sets the user property gardening experience
Call that method when the user selects the gardening experience dialog
Add array of possible generic levels in the strings.xml
atoms.positive_feedback:
Nice work! All setup to check on those User Properties. 

**Solution:** [[L03.02-Solution-LogAddToCartEvent](https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android/tree/L03.04-Solution-SetUserProperty)][[Diff](https://github.com/udacity/firebase-analytics-green-thumb-android/compare/L03.03-Solution-EventLoggingPractice...L03.04-Solution-SetUserProperty?expand=11)]
atoms.description: Using the example we just went through in Green Thumb, set the user property for gardening experience.
